title: HOT OR NOT: Josh Taylor has the chance to become one of Britain's biggest sporting stars
text:
It's Hot or Not time again as Sportsmail's Daniel Matthews reveals what's been making him feel warm and what's been leaving him cold this week...

HOT

JOSH TAYLOR

Scotland’s ‘Tartan Tornado’ takes on Regis Prograis in London on Saturday night: two unbeaten world champions vying for the Muhammad Ali Trophy in the 140lb World Boxing Super Series final. Taylor has potential to be among our biggest sport stars. Finally he’s getting the platform to show why.

Josh Taylor fights Regis Prograis for the Muhammad Ali Trophy at the 02 Arena on Saturday

THE OX

It can’t be overstated just how big Liverpool’s win over Genk was for Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain on Wednesday. This was the latest boost his career needed after injury woe. He could be a vital asset for club and country over the next 12 months.

EDDIE JONES

This week showed why the RFU put their trust in Eddie Jones. He was hired for games like Saturday's World Cup semi-final against New Zealand and he has again been in his element. The mind games have been relentless since England beat Australia and his call to change a winning XV showed he is prepared to go all-in when the stakes are high.

Eddie Jones has attempted every mind game in the book ahead of clash with New Zealand

NOT

ZLATAN IBRAHIMOVIC

After LA Galaxy’s defeat by LA FC in what could be his last match in MLS, the striker grabbed his crotch in response to taunts by fans. ‘If I don’t stay, nobody will remember what MLS is,’ he said. You do wonder if the self-proclaimed lion, 38, will ever grow up.

Zlatan Ibrahimovic grabbed his crotch in response to taunts from fans after LA Galaxy defeat

LEWIS HAMILTON

In the week Lewis Hamilton could seal a sixth world championship, it is what he does and says away from the track that is making news. Fernando Alonso accused him of hypocrisy over his call to save the planet and, with ‘a lot going on’ in his life Hamilton can only hope to have the final say at the wheel.

FIFA

The Premier League is planning to play matches nine days before the start of the 2022 World Cup and eight days after the final. It’s the latest evidence showing why playing it in winter is a bad idea and why giving it to Qatar wasn’t clever, either. But of course we knew all that.
